sentence: i was at opia january 5, 2006 we had some drinks, dinner, i have to say that we had me and my friend great time, the staff was listening, the manager knew what he was doing and the food better than ever!!
All-night restaurant with excellent burgers and stella on tap.
The waiter took my boyfriend's order, snatched away the menus and stormed away from the table without even looking at me.
We asked for a side of dressing but the waiter told us that all the salads just had oil and vinegar so we should just use the oil and vinegar that was on the table.
The pooris were miniscule, about 2 bites each; they serve 4 of those as a dinner for $25!
I tried the price fix and te waiter looked offended when I requested the price fix menu.
The bar was a disaster because there were no tables for anyone, and drinks took 20 minutes to receive.
The wine did not come until we were half way through our entree and the waitress overcharged us by a bottle of wine.
If you're going to label spicy items on your menu as spicy (like the Buffalo and Cajun wraps), I think you should go ahead and label all the spicy items as spicy.
They have recently fired their staff and brought in new people who dont even know how to serve a beer, I might add you are on average paying $6.
It's a small and quaint place so have your expectations in check, but that doesn't mean anything bad - know going in that you are gonna eat some serious food!
Luckily, I made reservations for our group or else it would have been a long wait.
i had a horrible experience with a waiter while trying to have breakfast friday morning.
The food was good but not worth the price.
The owner kindly gave us appetizers on the house to make our now, long wait, more pleasant, but of course they took forever to arrive and were insufficient.
At the end of the meal, I politely asked the waitress whether she would comp something, and she said yes.
They have possibly the worst service in New York I have waited until the waiter has finished his paper, begged for water and waited over an hour for my meal.
Worth the trip and the wait (and the higher than average price)?
Across the menu, and even within a single dish, there is a stunning variety of scintillating, distinct flavors.
Between the seven of us we sampled just about everything on the menu, and nothing disappointed (ribs pulled pork seemed like the biggest hits).
The mussles had be be a portion of maybe 8-9 mussles only and the gnocci were basically all garlic- garlic is just meant to be a condiment- way tooo much garlic.
We sat there with the check and ordered dessert and more drinks.
The service was a bit inadequate-and be warned they bring your food as it is ready- so be sure to order apps then after being served order entrees.
I tried several dishes, while at dinner with friends, and was amazed to discover that even their Caesar Salad was completely lacking in flavor.
Although the waitress had clearly our reservation on her book, she told us somebody arrived one minute ago and being first to arrive, he could have our table.
The music is a mix of house radio as well as live band at the same time.

There are a few things I can forgive at any popular place: somewhat long waits even with reservations, service staff that mistakenly believes they're there to act haughty rather than serve, and a way over-the-top interior.
It's very reasonably priced considering the size of portions.
I went with my sister and neither of us had wine so the final bill was a bit shocking.
When our entrees came, at least 3 or 4 waiters / waitresses came by at different times to wish us bon apetit.
The food came out really quick and the service overall was not bad.
A reservation did not save us from a wait at the bar, but the food was worth it; a grilled calamari appetizier with mushrooms was delicious as was a mixed seafood pasta main course.
Wonderful service, not too long a wait for tables, price is right - in a word, go!
I went there on my 2nd day in New York ever for a quick lunch and ended up staying and chatting with the owners wife and a waiter, Javi for two hours.
The kitchen is fast, but you sometime may have trouble getting a seat, since this place is very small.
For the price and quality of the food we got, I would not dine here again.
the waiter was extremely helpful, basically we gave him carte blanche to order small plates for us that he thought we'd like.
The bartender informed me the place was full, and the wait was 30 minutes.
it's one of the cheapest eats in the city and the food is not bad if you sit at the bar only - they have a decent chicken and/or beef tender tips but they cook with a lot of garlic so beware.
though the portions were smaller than average, the flavor and sauces that accompany them (truffle honey, cherries and peaches in mustard sauce) were all really good.

While the food was good enough (if old-fashioned - my meal tasted like it was out of a fancy 1950s cookbook, all creamy and rich) the environment was sort of bizarre - rich tapestries, yucky corner-grocer roses on the tables, and a strange '80s mirrored wall, which we sat against at the back of the restaurant.
An unpretentious sexy atmosphere lends itself to the above average wine-list and a menu that can stand-up to any other restaurant in NewYork City (or Paris).
The Scene Schnack feels a lot like a roller-rink concession stand circa 1982, from the deep vinyl booths and beat-up chairs right down to the loud music and plastic menu boards.
Our waiter didn't know the menu or the ingredients.
And forget about having a drink at the bar to take the edge off because the space between tables is so narrow that you'll be shoved by the wait staff who are desparate to get their job done.
We had a reservation for Monday lunch and were seated promptly, which was a pleasant surprise.
At one point, the waiter told us that he couldn't find our wine!
I went there for a late dinner last night with a friend and the service was aweful.

Our waiter disappeared entirely, our food, when we were finally able to order it, arrived without plates (we had to go and track down a busboy to get them), and when we were finished, we couldn't get the check, even after walking across the restaurant to request it.
We were seated promptly, and after an inordinate wait, somebody took our drink order and disappeared for half an hour.
Don't let the all-Italian menu intimidate; the waitstaff patiently translates each item.
very nice servers, but they seemed more interested in conversing with the regulars than bringing food and being attentive.
Great wine list with an extra expensive selection for all you big spenders.
The service was really bad at several points our waiter would just leave for a cigarette for like 10 minutes while we waited for him to get us another drink or even pay the bill.
We should have had the entire restaurant, but the manager let some random lady sit up at the bar because she was a regular.
After a 21/2 hour lunch in which our displeasure was apparent, we didn't receive an apology or an explanation from the waiter or manager.
last time, the waiter told my roommate he'd have to charge her $5 for mushrooms as one of her omelette choices (never heard that at my other favorite brunch places.
the manager said that they were just starting with a preview menu.
The service and atmosphere may not set your mood but when you're done you will realize that it's only the food that counts!

The place was packed and while our food took time to be prepared, our waiter earned points for his sparkling conversation to pass time and for also knowing practically every ingredient of every special under consideration.
When his to sons joined the mix they took Dads quest for the best food another step adding slowly to the menu a host of items that reflect the demigraphic of this still growing nabe.
The waiter messed up my order and we had to hunt down the wait staff to get a second drink.
Tony's gone, sadly Ernie's passed on and now the waiters have corn rows and less finish to their chosen profession but it still maintains it's class and place as a brooklyn landmark.
The wait staff was attentive without being overbearing, and our waiter gave thoughtful advice on dishes that would be suitable for the children.
Our waiter was a real pro; knew a lot about ingredients and allowed us to take our time.
I went back to telly's because i heard that they changed the Chef and the food was again, after a very very small break, was excellent again.
The numbness in your lower legs from sitting on old wood chairs is more than compensated by the wonderful food.
Our waiter didn't even bothered to ask for dessert.
Had the calves liver alla veneziana in a fine rich and complex sauce with perfectly fried onions.
Casual and kid-friendly, the red-and-gold colored restaurants offer quick drive-thru or dine-in service with a menu of burgers, sandwiches and more.
I like the smaller portion size for dinner.
Our food was delivered in a timely fashion but if you wanted another drink or your check you had to hunt down your server.
While we were trying to have dinner, all of the waiters spent their time playing with spilled milk at the counter, not paying any attention to the diners.
not fancy I think they keep their christmas decorations up all year long, but good mexican food!!
The waitress never came back to get drink refills and we didn't get water until we were halfway through our dinner.
Although, a limited menu, we had no trouble picking out our delicious meal.
And the room is VERY noisy, but I suppose that's because everyone is having a good time.
Also, neither our waiter or busboy ever came back to ask if we wanted more to drink or even refill our WATER glasses.
My friend ordered the scallops which were served in a light red sauce that was complemented very nicely with atichoke palms.
No dress codes, no attitudes, plenty of comfort companionship, a great place to relax in an always busy Midtown.
When spending upwards of $200 for dinner for two, I expect better service.
This past Memorial day weekend was hot and I asked the waiter why was the air condition not working and he responded doens't know why.
The white tablecloths covering closely-packed, old wood tables; waitresses with accents and up-turned noses; warm firelight ambience; boisterous crowds drinking wine -- it's all here.
They served the salad and the main course together and didn't even bring the dessert menu.
I am hoping the stale service was a one shot deal because it wads deplorable for what we paid for dinner!
It has the most authentic Mexican found I have found in the Metro area and the margaritas are outstanding.
They were out of cherry, so we got a few slices of apple and one key lime.
But then there's the sluggish and absentminded service: twice someone tried to serve us something for another table and it took a long time to get our check.
The waitress took about 20 minutes to bring us the menu.

The menu features such sumptuous fare as lobster ravioli in a light aurora sauce, double-cut grilled veal chop with an aromatic salsa verde, and octopus salad with steamed potato, red onions, and caper berries.
For the cost of the lunch I expected much better service.
Otoro tuna, gorgeously marbled with fat, is captivating; hamachi sashimi, topped by the chef with a whisper of sea salt and a barely-there squeeze of lemon, creates eye-rolling pleasure.
I love the creative rolls that they have on their menus, and none of them were a disappointment.
the menu looked great, but the food was the biggest disappointment i've had yet!

Well I can't tell you how the food was because the moment we walked in, the single waiter was extremely rude and told us to wait outside while he cleared a table (in the middle of winter) because he was busy.
People were leaving because they had been waiting for hours, however we decided to stay and have a complimentary drink at the bar which was absoloutely beautiful along with the view, the only plus.
Our waiter snubbed us when we asked if there was dessert (there wasn't), and my meal would have been the same price had it not been restaurant week.
They bought the same surly staff, it still took way too long for food, drink, ANY SERVICE and the food is still $ 12.
At 1:15 we were still waiting for our plates!
A friend was dieing for chorizo but it was only in the tapas menu which we couldn't have.
The ambience is horrible but the food is incredible.
Best value is the sushi/sashimi lunch combo - get the large for double pieces on sushi!
The filet was NOT on the menu, but my friend had the bouillabaisse, which he found delicious.
The fondue was good, but not worth the very expensive price tag.
Appetizers took their sweet time in coming, and literally about an hour later we had our main dishes which were very small considering the price.
There is no menu and the waiter never told us how much lunch was, I thought it couldn't be more than $35.
Having heard that the steakhouse had a tendency to overcook the steaks, I asked the waitress that she ask the chef to prepare it closer to rare than medium.
If you can get a corner table you can see the entire room while eating in elegance.
The service always ruins your food if it's poor.
Cute decor, but rather small so the dining room can get very smoky if the bar is crowded.
People will literally spend their entire lunch break waiting and for what - an average fastfood burger.
The owner and his sister make you feel like you've been invited over to their house for dinner.
After our waitress brought us menus took our drink orders, a diff hostess came over asked us to give up our table.
We were a large group and would highly recommend all the drinks and foodThe manager on duty was understanding that our friends were very late and held our reservation.
Sometimes service was a bit slow, and we had to ask for salads, water, etc a couple of times, but this was all done with good humor and no resentment.
Try a traditional latin favorite like Arroz con pollo (yellow rice w/ chicken red bell pepper) but meat lovers should definitely not miss out on the churrasco!
The best dish is not listed on their menu - it is a special - the flat pasta with truffle mushroom sauce.

We had reserved space one one side of the bar, but when the staff tried to force the Pre-Fixe on all 15 members of the party to stay there, we moved to the other side (the difference in decor was minimal).
Every item on the menu tasted like it had been lovingly perfected- from the pulled pork sandwich on white roll to the smokey baked beans, buttery mac-n-cheese, and slightly spicey coleslaw.
their Stella on tap was almost flat, i saw the bartender whisking our beers to give them any sort of head.
The Food Despite a menu that seems larger than the restaurant, great care goes into the preparation of every dish.
we told the waitress and she told us that we ordered the dead fish as opposed to the swimming fish.
yes Shrimp not lobster (those are 6 Lbs) try the exotic Fish not on the menu and a must have is the Flower stuffed with lump crab meat.

The food is definitely the attraction, but the service has been consistently bad on every visit.

Try Le Madeleine for a similar price but much better food.

I expected high prices at Nello, but as I looked at the menu my eyes became as large as the Birkin Mary-Kate has been seen toting around these days--$18 for soup, $22 for a plate of mixed greens, $40 for pasta.
Bins of fresh bagels rest behind the counter, and there are always a few customers sitting at one of the few tables inside or on one of two wooden benches out front.

Our dinner took over two hours because of the slow service.

We organized a party at this bar and have gotten very poor service.
The chef insisted that the meat was cooked properly!?
Service is not what one would expect from a joint in this price category.
I will say that often times they make their drinks very strong (may tell your bartender / waitress to keep it mild).

We ordered 1/2 bottle of Gruner, 2 appetizers - foie gras and oysters, 2 entrees - steak and diver scallops, and 1 dessert, the pastry chef's favorite a mixture of crushed avocado, salt glazed caramel and lime sorbet (which really tasted like margarita infused guacamole, to try only if you're feeling wd-50 adventurous) for around $100.

Very pleasant atmosphere, not a quiet romantic dinner.
Service: Below Average, the staff joked stood around in the dinning room joking around with each other.

My friends and I had a great time - the atmosphere was exciting but didn't encroach on us while we had our meal and drinks (which is better, the kiwitini or the watermelon martini?)

the best thing is the atmosphere, but even that is overshadowed by the lack of taste and originality in the food.

food for fancy prices; menu consisted of one page; antipasto, and pizza; that was pretty much it; the other 3 pages was to my surprize the wine list.

had dinner there last night, max the waiter was great.

The service is disorganised, no one gave us a menu for 15 mins once we were seated, but after that it went smoothly enough but no where near the stella performance of many half as pretensious restaurants.

junk food place that could do well with a good cleaning.

The place was extremely busy, and with food like this why not.

We had to request water and chips (tostades) and salsa three times (the third time my date had to go and track down the waitress) before finally being served (by the busser) and the place wasn't even a quarter full.

Only reason to go is Eben, the most solicitious bartender in NYC (now) with drink knowledge and ability to spare.

The waiter did not take a drink order from us.
(food was delivered by a busboy, not waiter) We got no cheese offered for the pasta, our water and wine glasses remained EMPTY our entire meal, when we would have easily spent another $20 on wine.
I went for lunch and the staff does not welcome you upon entering.

I excused myself from my table went downstairs to inform the hostess that I would like to suprise my dinner guest by recognizing his birthday in a very understated way.
The atmosphere is perfect, whether sitting down for dinner or just having a drink at the bar and engaging the friendly bartenders in converasation.

after such a strong showing, dessert was a letdown per our waiters recommendation, we ordered the raspberry softie the coconut-stuffed apricots the softie tasted like a mixture between cough syrup a starburst, whereas the apricots were extremely sour.
The wait staff is friendly and helpful and kudos to the sushi chef Hero who serves up great dishes on and off the menu and is always wearing a smile.
WAY OVER PRICED , HAD MUCH BETTER MEALS FOR JUST OVER HALF THE PRICE IN PLACES JUST AS NICE.
The food was delicious, and the menu provided ample choices which suited all of the eaters in our party from the most daring to the most conservative.

however, we went for lunch and were the only ones eating there and yet the service seemed eager for us to be done and to get out.

Don't ask for a menu- take the trip with your waiter who eloquently (and vividly) describes dishes until he sees your eyes light up.

We waited at the bar for only 10 minutes (we had a reservation) - can't complain about that, the restaurant was full and I enjoyed the lively atmosphere and music.
Much to my satisfaction, I was seated promptly without a reservation and soon after being seated was greeted by my server.
The restaurant didn't mind me sitting on their doorstep to the extent that the bartender invited me in for a drink.
Again in a group 6 months ago, the service was even worse this time, practically begging for water and other drinks while we waited an age just to get our orders taken.

it's a joy to watch the chef work, who refused to take my order but seeing him open my live scallop made me understand why.

on the food-front while adding just enough of a civilized atmosphere where you won't worry about either your neighbor or the wait staff biting off one of your fingers.

Well, its bar is beginning to attract the high-heeled Forever 21 ladies and hair-gelled men-who-love-them crowd (alas) and yet I must admit-- the food is damn good.

impressive balcony seating and while they forgot to give us the cold appetizers, the waiter and maitre'd more than made up for it by being most accomodating to us.

The service is sweet and attentive, the wine is delicious and the new wine bar around the corner has the most amazing selection, as well as cheeses and tapas.
Waiter was a strange bird and when told we wanted to enjoy our dining experience and not be rushed through dinner, he assured us it takes 30 minutes to get entrees once food was ordered.
After being seated took our waiter 10 mintues to get us a menu, 15 minutes to come back for our order, by the time we finally got our food it was almost 1 1/2 hour since getting there.
We had at least 10 of the appetizers on the menu, which all were delicious.
It was somewhere between our waiter not knowing what sushi came as part of the tasting platter and the copious amounts of wine that he spilt while trying to pour me a taste that I realized.
The menu is slightly different from downtown, but they still have my favorites -- madai salad with hot sesame oil, shrimp kanzuri, the diamond roll, the crispy shrimp roll.
One of my friends told them it was my birthday and the staff relally surprised me when their came to me singing with the mexican hats and a dessert with a candle on it.
The sangria was served quickly and often.
All in all, I would not recommend for the food or drinks but I guess I can't expect better for the prices.
not only were we waiting for half an hour with reservations, once we got seated we waited another 15+ minutes for the waiter to come and take out drink menu.
The waiter brought us the desert menu, and when we refused asked if we were really sure we didn't want anything.
I for one do not plan to go back, there are many other places in Manhattan that have just as good food if not better, at the same prices with much better service.
better for dining with friends/significant others.
We fully relied on our very capable waiter for choices of the menu and we were not disappointed.
And when I received my $9 glass of wine, I had to ask the waitress if she planned on putting more in -- there was hardly any liquid in the glass!
Recently I purchased a dish to go, and found that all of my meal contained just one large piece of ginger root.

The service was average - the waiter did not check in on our meals and did not even refill the water, but was a bit pushy on desert (we both ordered schnapps).

Our server was just fantastic, she recommended that we order a lot of different dishes, so we did, we tried almost everything on the menu, we were a party of six and the whole group enjoyed everything.

Food is pretty good but the service is horrific.

This place is decent if you want to hang out with friends (who don't mind paying up) in a low-key atmosphere with good food, but don't mind putting up with sub-par level of service.
When you're sitting in their main dining room (which has a spectacular, hand-painted high ceiling) you'd never know there was a world outside.
The retaurant is know for the long wait but they do take reservation for group of 5-8 people, so it was just perfect for my friend BD dinner for 3 couples.

And the waiter actually replied, yes that's why it took you so long to get a reservation.
we saw another waitress spill hot coffee on another diner's foot.
Great place for either appetizers and drinks at the bar, a romantic dinner or late night partying.
Coffee served without sugar/milk and took more than 10 min to catch the waiter to ask for it.
There is no waiting area, so we had a crowd hovering over our table, this is just testament to how many people want to eat there.
We waited over 30 minutes to get our drinks (which were brought over my the manager) and we could not find anyhting that looked interesting on the menu.
The food was good but for the prices, it was definitely not worth it.
Smiling servers quiz diners with movie trivia, but forget to fill their water glasses.
Service only so-so -- I saw a lot of wait staff standing around, and at the busiest moment, I watched waiter stroll through the dining room with two plates as if he had all the time in the world.
Did not get to dessert as it took a while to get the server's attention and we had a show to get to.
Never will you taste sicilian Pizza and Spumoni like LBs.

There are no vegetarian items on the menu, but when I requested that the chef make something meat-free for me, he came through with a dish just as delicious and pretty as those my friends were eating.
Our waiter took his time taking our drink orders ('97 Italian red was good).
The service and surroundings couldn't have been better, but the food was very disapointing at best.
The food was simple but exploded with flavor and the presentation was as if it was out of a cook book.
If she was a bit more sophisticated, she wouldn't have been impressed with the list, but rather with the clientele and atmosphere.
Hoegardden on tap is an added bonus if you're not drinking from the well versed wine menu.
I had dinner with a few of my friends, and it was the best we've had in a long time.
The wait staff had good recommendations and when i broke a wine glass, they reacted in a way to put me out of my embarrassment quickly and even filled me a new glass of wine.
A 3 course-meal took 2 1/2 hours, including 20 - 30 minutes waiting to get the check after dessert.

We went out on the town with the idea that we were going to mingle with the in crowd, you know, go to a place where you pay an outrageous cover charge, have to wear all black to fit in, and pay $12 for a watered-down martini, and if you're lucky, have a good time.
I went to Mocca with my boyfriend for a few drinks and food, and I was really impressed by the service.

The drinks are very pricey and small, and the food is ok - but the portion size for the price is outrageous.
The Sushi was of the highest caliber, the cut as if a master samurai marks smith was behind the bar, and service, just what you would expect from a fine dining establishment, New York style.
Tried it again for brunch, when the service was worse.
You cannot beat having the waiter spooning butter over your steak before you are served!!

If it was outstanding I could see it as a nice change for lunch, but the peanut butter wasn't any better than one you could buy at any grocery store and the chocolate peanut butter brownie was horrible.
The food was barely decent and our server was nowhere to be found.
The food is good and cheap BUT the attitudes of the bartender and wait staff are almost unbearable.

Everything on the menu is satisfyingly savory, from a simple pot of mussels in a choice of sauces (beer-and-bacon, creamy mushroom, or white-wine-and-garlic broth), to beef stewed with beer and prunes, to a juicy croque-monsieur, and beyond.
A good restaurant would have at least comped desert or sent over a round of drinks for such a long wait -- we didn't even get an apology from a manager.

staff is still working out their kinks and learning about the menu but no real complaints.

Yes, the wait is long and ridiculous as times, especially as you watch others gobble down their food.

To start with - the maitre'd forgot our reservation and then when it came time to sit us down - he told us we only had an hour.
Dining experience begins with cracked, filthy vinyl tile flooring tables so small close together that you couldn't move.
Dishes feature intriguing names, and interesting combinations of fresh ingredients.

Menu had several fish selections (snapper, salmon, cod) but all were around $30 despite the fact that the portions would hardly fill a child's belly and the sides were 3 pieces of lettuce (literally).
However the casual atmosphere comes in handy if you want a good place to drop in and get food.

While waiting we asked the bartender for at glass of red wine which he not only forgot to serve but when we asked him again 10min later he poured us white wine.
Hillarious lighting and ecclectic side dishes make you want to love the place, but the meal on the whole was abyssmal.
The menu had some slight twists to conventional upscale Mexican.

too bad that the 2 sushi chefs have become a bit too busy to chat away with the guests at the counter, but they try and hey, we are here for the food !!!
For the price ($8), the quality of the buffet is great!

The interior is understated making it special enough to take a date but easy enough to stop in anytime for dinner or snack.
the place had open doors and windows and a very relaxed, candle-lit type of atmosphere.

Start off with an expertly mixed cocktail or glass of wine at the beautiful bar.

FINALLY the waitress came with our food after an HOUR!
Dining choices range from three-course, ingredient-themed tasting menus or a regular, seasonal a la carte menu.

The Food Despite the restaurant's name, the menu is remarkably Atkins-friendly, from the nibble bowls of spicy fried chickpeas to the grilled slabs of salt-flecked, smoky rib-eye, succulent chunks of rosemary roast chicken and fat tubes of springy grilled squid.
servers never ONCE asked how we were doing - they brought out food late and if extra additions were requested, they came out 20 min after.

We went on a Monday night around 6:30pm and were seated right away in the backroom, which is dimly-lit, casual, cozy--kind of felt like you were sitting in a spacious dining galley of a ship or a cabin.
5 hour meal (we ordered the tasting menu).

The service was lacking a bit, we waited about 20 mins for a waiter and water to come to us once we were sat and we had to ask for everything twice, even drink orders - I think maybe we just got stuck with a bad waiter though.
The snooty manager asked us to leave and gave us our check in the middle of our meal.
